description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located about two kilometers from the thermal area and a 10 to 15 minutes drive depending on the traffic. The entire area is dotted with temples, palaces, and towers that are very beautiful. Some are seriously damaged by the recent earthquake and are being restored, but few temples are functional. The square has access to several hotels and restaurants.
fun_fact: The Kumari, or living goddess, who is considered to be an incarnation of the goddess Taleju, resides in the Kumari Ghar built in 1757 by King Jayaprakash Malla.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is located in the heart of capital Kathmandu. It is one of the three durbar squares in the capital, the other being Patan Durbar Square and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Unlike the other two durbar squares, this one served as the home for the kings of our country Nepal. After the unification, a big palace was built within the area for the kings to live in, but as of now it serves as a museum. Kathmandu Durbar Square is often known as a place where different kings ruled our country for generations. It is also a home to the living goddess Kumari. The area is a host to a lot of interesting local festivals throughout the year, with Indra Jatra being one of the very well-known festivals that goes on for a week straight.
fun_fact: The current Kumari is just about 6 years of age.

cultural_activities.description: A well-known festival that goes on for a week straight.

historical_events.description: Most of the temples and monuments were partially or completely damaged during the earthquake.
A significant historical event after which a big palace was built for the kings.
